text: Mañana – That in a word is the sum of the Prime Minister’s summit statement. Here’s a full text.

text: Already aware. but thanks. Not I think quite correct to say "no longer matters" because EU law would be out of kilter with UK law were Parliament to refuse to pass an SI removing the date from the act.

text: Your first five words: amen.

text: Might the Speaker rule that a Minister who acts freelance and moves such an SI is in order?
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text:
Suppose the Minister in question is, oh I don't know, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, acting freelance...???

Crazy question, perhaps.  But crazy times.
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text: It seems to be unlikely.
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text: So even this Speaker can't find a way of permitting a backbencher to move an SI proposing extension?
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text: The Speaker will be studying those provisions very closely...
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text: Yes, if you can get a definitive ruling to that effect from the Speaker...

text: Who can move an SI?

text: Big straw in the wind from @JohnnyMercerUK on @ConHome. Tory MPs should present members with a final four candidates, not two. Would make it more like that an ERG and even a Second Referendum candidate would get into the final. https://bit.ly/2FgkO0L  (Expect more of this.)

text: Nothing to do with anyone being in anything for the money or not. It's a means of expressing no confidence in a Minister.  Commons Library note cites [adopts Bercow voice] precedent from June 21 1885 (and others).

text: "When I cite a precedent," Humpty Bercow said, in rather a scornful tone, "it means just what I choose it to mean—neither more nor less."
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text: Bercow summary: May can't bring back her deal as MV3 if it's the same as MV2.  Crucial point: he and he alone will decide if the two are sufficiently different.
author: PaulGoodmanCH

text: "If we only went by precedent, manifestly nothing would ever change" - John Bercow, Januay 2019.

text:
"Tory MPs should vote for the Government's revised Brexit deal if it is put to the Commons again: 40% https://bit.ly/2T9yP5C 

"The Gvt's proposed Brexit deal is acceptable to me": 19% https://bit.ly/2T9SPF9 

No backstop mention in either statement - time limit or otherwise.
